statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Greg Monroe delivered 14 points and seven rebounds in his college debut, and anchored a suffocating defense that helped Georgetown build a lead and then hold on to beat Jacksonville 71-62 on Monday night.
article.headline: Freshman Monroe scores 14, makes difference on defense against Jacksonville
article.linkText: Monroe stars in debut as Georgetown escapes

inlines.body:
Fast Facts

• Georgetown won its fourth straight home opener and ninth in 10 years.

• The two teams combined to shoot 8-for-43 (18.6 percent) from 3-point range.

• The Hoyas extended their home winning streak to 23 and their winning streak against unranked non-conference opponents to 21.

-- ESPN research

article.story: WASHINGTON -- The arena lights dimmed, the PA announcer told fans to "Get on your feet and make some noise!" -- and Greg Monroe was the first Georgetown player introduced to the crowd. Then the game against Jacksonville began, and the 6-foot-11 freshman was the first Georgetown player to shoot the ball this season. And the first to score. And the first to grab a rebound. And the first to block a shot. All in all, it was quite an introduction to college basketball for Monroe, who replaced the graduated Roy Hibbert at center for the Hoyas and delivered 14 points and seven rebounds Monday night, helping Georgetown (No. 18 ESPN/USA Today, No. 22 AP) beat Jacksonville 71-62. "He has to touch the ball," Georgetown coach John Thompson III said. "Good things will happen for our team when he touches the ball." Monroe also anchored Georgetown's typically stout defense, getting credit for three blocks and forcing opponents to alter several shots. Jacksonville missed its first eight field goal tries en route to shooting only 28 percent for the first half and 35 percent for the game. Many misses came from beyond the new, farther 3-point line: Jacksonville went 3-for-20 (15 percent) from there. Thanks mainly to Monroe and new starting guard Chris Wright, who had 16 points, five rebounds and four assists, the Hoyas won their first game without departed seniors Hibbert, Jonathan Wallace and Patrick Ewing Jr. "It's the first game, and we played most of the game with freshmen and sophomores," Thompson said. "We have to grow. We have to learn." He chided his team for hoisting too many 3-point attempts, instead of working the ball inside more. The Hoyas shot only 5-for-23 on 3s. "It's kind of expected for us to have those type of woes in the first game, shooting so poorly from the 3," forward DaJuan Summers said. Summers and Jessie Sapp, the lone returning scholarship senior, each scored 13 points for Georgetown (1-0). Ben Smith led Jacksonville (0-2) with 17 points -- 15 after halftime. "He woke up in the second half," Jacksonville coach Cliff Warren said. "I had some choice words for him." This was hardly supposed to be a tough nonconference tuneup for Georgetown, which beat Jacksonville by 32 points last season. But Smith's 3 with 7:18 to go pulled Jacksonville within 54-47. Moments later, Monroe picked up his fourth foul and went to the bench, and Marcus Allen's inside basket made it 54-49 with a little under 6 minutes left. Allen's free throws 30 seconds later cut Georgetown's lead to 55-51. "Our team was getting very anxious," Sapp said. But Summers scored half of the Hoyas' next 14 points as they pulled away. He said it "wasn't odd; it was different" playing without Hibbert and Wallace. Hibbert was the Hoyas' top scorer and rebounder last season, and his 7-2 presence was key as Georgetown led the nation in field goal percentage defense. Wallace topped the team in 3-pointers, was its third-leading scorer and started every game for four years. Now Wright -- a sophomore who missed most of last season with a broken foot -- has taken Wallace's spot, and Monroe -- a prized recruit from Louisiana -- is manning the middle. Monroe took advantage of an opportunity to open up against a Jacksonville starting five with no one taller than 6-7. Monroe didn't speak to the media after the game; Georgetown doesn't let freshmen basketball players take questions until January. But everyone else was willing to offer praise. "He can score. He can rebound. He can face up. He can pass. He can think the game," Warren said. "He's just a very poised young man." Monroe cut to the basket to drop in Wright's assist on the game's opening possession, though not without some hesitation. "Well, he got involved early. First play of the game," Wright said. "Everybody could see he was kind of nervous: He stumbled. But he made the shot." The second time Jacksonville had the ball, Monroe grabbed an air ball. The next time, he swatted Ayron Hardy's shot. Jacksonville didn't score until more than 4 minutes elapsed, on two free throws by Szymon Lukasiak. Less than a minute later, though, Lukasiak was having one shot blocked and another altered by Monroe. "He's talented, and we're going to need him to produce," Wright said. "I mean, Greg has a lot on his shoulders."
